lines.text: I've got a really great compliment for you, and it's true.
I'm so afraid you're about to say something awful.

Clearly, a mistake. I've got this, what - ailment? My doctor, a shrink that I used to go to all the time, he says that in fifty or sixty percent of the cases, a pill really helps. I *hate* pills, very dangerous thing, pills. Hate. I'm using the word "hate" here, about pills. Hate. My compliment is, that night when you came over and told me that you would never... all right, well, you were there, you know what you said. Well, my compliment to you is, the next morning, I started taking the pills.
I don't quite get how that's a compliment for me.
You make me want to be a better man.
...That's maybe the best compliment of my life.
Well, maybe I overshot a little, because I was aiming at just enough to keep you from walking out.

I might be the only person on the face of the earth that knows you're the greatest woman on earth. I might be the only one who appreciates how amazing you are in every single thing that you do, and how you are with Spencer, "Spence," and in every single thought that you have, and how you say what you mean, and how you almost always mean something that's all about being straight and good. I think most people miss that about you, and I watch them, wondering how they can watch you bring their food, and clear their tables and never get that they just met the greatest woman alive. And the fact that I get it makes me feel good, about me.
I can't resist! You usually move through here so quickly and I just have so many questions I want to ask you. You have no idea what your work means to me.
What does it mean to you?

[stands up]
When somebody out there knows what it's like...
[place one hand on her forehead and the other over her heart]
... to be in here.
Oh God, this is like a nightmare.
[Turns around and presses the elevator button multiple times]
Oh come on! Just a couple of questions. How hard is that?
[Scampers up to Melvin]
How do you write women so well?
I think of a man, and I take away reason and accountability.
You're a disgrace to depression.

Where do they teach you to talk like this? In some Panama City "Sailor wanna hump-hump" bar, or is it getaway day and your last shot at his whiskey? Sell crazy someplace else, we're all stocked up here.
People who talk in metaphors oughta shampoo my crotch.

[to a group of depressed psychiatric patients]
What if this is as good as it gets?

[introducing Carol to Simon]
Carol the waitress, Simon the fag.

Never, never, interrupt me, okay? Not if there's a fire, not even if you hear the sound of a thud from my home and one week later there's a smell coming from there that can only be a decaying human body and you have to hold a hanky to your face because the stench is so thick that you think you're going to faint. Even then, don't come knocking. Or, if it's election night, and you're excited and you wanna celebrate because some fudgepacker that you date has been elected the first queer president of the United States and he's going to have you down to Camp David, and you want someone to share the moment with. Even then, don't knock. Not on this door. Not for ANY reason. Do you get me, sweetheart?

[clears his throat]
Uhm, yes. It's not a... subtle point that you're making.
Okay then.
[Shuts door in Simon's face]
OK, we all have these terrible stories to get over, and you-...

It's not true. Some of us have great stories, pretty stories that take place at lakes with boats and friends and noodle salad. Just no one in this car. But, a lot of people, that's their story. Good times, noodle salad. What makes it so hard is not that you had it bad, but that you're that pissed that so many others had it good.
I'm drowning here, and you're describing the water!
Thank you, Melvin. You... overwhelm me.
[pauses]
I love you.
I tell you, buddy... I'd be the luckiest guy alive if that did it for me.
When you first entered the restaurant, I thought you were handsome... and then, of course, you spoke.
Why can't I have a normal boyfriend? Just a regular boyfriend, one that doesn't go nuts on me!
Everybody wants that, dear. It doesn't exist.

[Seeing Carol undressed, in only a towel, on the edge of the bathtub]
Hold it.
[Turns on light, startling Carol]
I have to draw you.
Huh?
I have to draw you.
No, no no, absolutely not. I'm a lot more shy than people think. I give off the wrong impression.
I have to. I haven't sketched anything in weeks.
Stop staring. Do a vase.
But you're beautiful, Carol. Your skin, your long neck, the back, the line of you. You're why cavemen chiseled on walls.

[Smiles, and laughs slightly]
All right, cut me a break.
[as Simon draws, she smiles, and lowers her towel, giving him a better view]

[after a brief cutaway to a different scene, returning to this one; now Carol is laying on a couch, nude, laughing, as Simon draws]
I'm sorry, I don't care how you put this, we're being naughty here, pal.
No, no, this is, this is great.This is so great. I swear to God, my hand won't even keep up. Hold it. Hold it.
But I was just turning.
But then hold that. Hold any of them.
[the camera shows a pile of sketches that Simon has made of Carol]
OK, this?
It doesn't matter. My hand's not even bothering me. I can't - I just can't get the angle with this cast.
[Starts breaking the plaster cast off of his hand/wrist]
Oh, careful.
[Finished breaking cast off of his hand, and lets out a mock yell of pain, then both he and Carol start laughing]

[enters his psychiatrist's office]
Hi.
[shuts door]
*Help!*
If you want to see me, you will not do this. You will make an appointment.
Dr. Green, how can you diagnose someone as an obsessive compulsive disorder, and then act like I have some choice about barging in here?
To hell with sex! It was better than sex! We held each other! What I needed, he gave me great.
Police! Donut-munching morons, HELP ME! HELP ME!
Shh!
Assault and Battery - and you're black!

[after Carol arrives at Melvin's apartment in the middle of the night]
I'm not going to sleep with you! I will never sleep with you, never, ever! Not ever!
Well, I'm sorry, but, um... we don't open for the "no sex oaths" until 9am.
Fucking H.M.O. bastard pieces of shit!
Carol!
Sorry.
It's okay. Actually, I think that's their technical name.

[Sitting in the bar after Carol storms out]
Well, it's not right to go into details, I got nervous. I screwed up, I said the wrong thing... Where if I hadn't, I could be in bed right now with a woman who, if you make her laugh, you got a life. Instead I'm here with you
[gestures to bartender]
. No offense, but a moron pushing the last legal drug.
Do you want to dance?
I've been thinking about that for a while.

[standing up]
Well?
No.
Judging from your eyes, I'd say you were fifty.
Judging from your eyes, I'd say you were kind, so so much for eyes.
The best thing you have going for you is your willingness to humiliate yourself.
I can't get back to my old life. She's evicted me from my life!
Did you really like it all that much?
Rot in hell, Melvin!
No need to stop being a lady. Quit worryin! You'll be back on your knees in no time!
I grew up in hell! My grandmother has more attitude than you!
I can't do this without you. I'm afraid he might pull the stiff one-eye on me.
Melvin, do you know where you're lucky? You know who you want.
Can I ask you a personal question?
Sure.
You ever get an erection over a woman?
Melvin...
I mean, wouldn't your life be easier if you weren't...
You consider your life easy?

[pause]
All right, I give you that one.
Come on in, and try not to ruin everything by being you.
Maybe we could live *without* the wisecracks.
Maybe we could.

[to Dr. Bettes, Spencer's wonderful new doctor]
Can we get you anything else? Water, coffee, couple of female slaves?
Can you drive him?
Think white, and get serious!
Just a little too much reality for a Friday night.

Okay... What I do is, I watch. Ever watch somebody who doesn't know you're watching them? An old woman sitting on a bus? Or kids going to school? Somebody just waiting, and you see this flash come over them. And you know immediately that has nothing to do with anything external because that hasn't changed. They're just sort of realer and more alive. You look at someone long enough, you discover their humanity.
If you stare at someone long enough, you discover their humanity.
You like sad stories? Wanna hear mine?
Have you ever let a romantic moment make you do something that you knew was stupid?
If there's a mental health organization that raises money for people like you, be sure to let me know.
Last word freak.
Do you have any control over how creepy you allow yourself to get?
Yes I do, as a matter of fact. And to prove it, I have not gotten personal, and you have.
My wife is Melvin Udall's publisher. She said that I was to take excellent care of this little guy because you are urgently needed back at work. What kind of work do you do?
I'm a waitress.
In Manhattan.
Oh, you were talking about your dog. I thought you were referring to that colored man inside your apartment.
Uh, what color would that be?
Like uh, like thick MO-lasses.
Is it a secret what you're doing here?
I had to see you.
Because?
It relaxes me. I'd feel better sitting ouside your apartment on the curb than any other place I can think of or imagine.
[last lines]
Want something?
Warm rolls.

[to Verdell the dog]
Don't be like me. Don't you be like me!

Is this fun for you? You lucky devil. It just keeps getting better and better, doesn't it? I'm losing my apartment, Melvin. And Frank, he wants me to beg my parents, who haven't called me, for help. And I won't. And... I... I don't want to paint any more. So the life that I was trying for, is over. the life that I had is gone, and I'm feeling so damn sorry for myself that it's difficult to breathe.

[finishing his latest romance novel]
"'You saved my life,' she said... 'You'd better make it up to me.'"
Did you have sex with her?
[Carol comes out of the bathroom]
Oh, sorry. I didn't know she was here. Did you have sex with her?
Just what the world needs, another actress.
You're going to die soon with that diet. You know that, right?
Oh, we're all going to die soon. I will, you will, and it sure sounds like your son will.
There are Jews at my table.
How are you?
Don't ask. I'm tired of my own complaints. I need to get some new thoughts.
Why? What are you thinking about now?
How to die, mostly.
To think that in our little mix you're the good roommate.
How much more you got to eat? Appetites aren't as big as your noses, huh?

[after telling Carol that he thinks she's the greatest woman on Earth]
Is that something that's bad for you to be around, for you?
No.
Lucky for you... you're here for rock-bottom. You absolute horror of a human being.
Verdell. What's wrong? You miss the tough guy?
[imitating Melvin]
Well, here I am, sweetheart! Happy to see me, you little pissant mop? How 'bout another ride down the chute?

[dumping Verdell down the garbage chute]
This is New York, pal. If you can make it here, you can make it anywhere!
I don't get this place. They make me buy a new outfit and let you in a housedress. I don't get it.
I need you to chaperone separate everything but cars you said you liked convertibles now I'm on the hook
I'm sorry, "stiff one eye ?", I can't, I work
You get off when you want to
My son
The vet says his doing fine
I'd rather not
What's that got to do with it?
Funny, I thought it strong point
"Write a note isn't she sweet?" I need a hand and where'd she go?
You're saying accepting your help obligates me?
Is there any other way to see it?

I'm sure Simon they did something really "off" in order for you to feel this way but when it comes to your parents or your kids something will always be "off" unless you set it straight and maybe this thing happened to you so you have a chance to do that

When I was a kid I always painted and my mother always encouraged it , she was very fabulous about it, I was too young to think that there was anything wrong with it, so she used to pose nude for me, I always thought or I assumed my father knew about it, one day he found us and started screaming I was trying to defend my mother and make peace in the lamest way, I said " she's not naked, it's art" and he started hitting me and beat me unconscious, he taught me a lesson he thought I'd never forget, he knew what I was even before I did, the morning I left for college he walked into my room and held out his hand and it was filled with money, a big sweaty wad of money and he said, " take this and I don't want you ever to come back", I grabbed him and hugged him and he turned around and walked out I haven't seen him or talked to him since
[Carol kisses him on the cheek]

[Sees Melvin making a fuss of Verdell]
Aw, I'd like to be treated like that!

[reading from her own note cards one by one]
Simon, you're broke the medical bills are sixty one thousand now and the show didn't go well I've spoken to your parents they didn't hang up or anything but they say they'd feel strange if they called you
You know, they let you in with a housedress, yet they make me find a jacket.
[Carol gets up to leave]
Whoa, whoa, where are you going?
Pay me a compliment, Melvin. I need one. You have no idea how much that hurt my feelings.
The life I was trying for is gone, but it's high times for you, isn't it Mr Udall? The gay neighbour's terrified. Terrified!
I will tell you why the dog prefers me, now. It's a trick! I carry bacon.

[finished with yelling at Melvin]
I HATE doing this! I'm an Art Dealer!
Love that dog.
You don't love anything, Mr Udall.
How old are you? Because going by your eyes I'd say you were fifty!
Ha! Going by your eyes I'd say you were kind. So much for eyes.
No, when I first saw you I thought you were handsome. Then, of course, you opened your mouth...
You can take my car, a convertible. Do you drive?
Like the wind, BUT I'M NOT DOIN' IT!
Gettin' loud.
I've got Jews at my table.
It's not your table, behave! This once, you can sit at someone else's station.
[all the other waitresses gasp]
Or you can wait your turn.

[Melvin enters the restaurant in his suit]
You look so se-... um, you look great. You look great.
I'm dying here.
Because you love her.
No! And you people are supposed to be sensitive and sharp?

[crying and laughing at the same time]
Over a dog! Over an ugly dog!

[Melvin has once again insulted her without realizing it]
Forget I said that.
I'll never forget you said it.
As long as you keep your work zipped up around me, I don't give a rat-crap what or where you shove your show. Are we done being neighbors for now?
A compliment is something nice about somebody else.
Waiting gives the devil time.

[Typing away]
At last she was able to define love... Love was...? Ah!
[Thumping at the door]
Oh, now I'm pissed! Now I'm really pissed!
